Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the effectiveness of the silver solution by stating that it "totally eliminates" and "kills" the coronavirus, without sufficient evidence to support these claims.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough scientific evidence or studies to support the effectiveness of the silver solution in eliminating the coronavirus.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the silver solution, which has been tested on other strains of the coronavirus, will also be effective against the specific strain causing COVID-19, without providing any evidence or scientific basis for this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued warning statements to companies, including the one promoting the silver solution, to stop selling products claiming to cure the coronavirus.
Understate: The claim understates the potential dangers and side effects of using colloidal silver, which can have negative health effects such as skin discoloration and interference with the absorption of certain drugs and antibiotics.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or treatments for the coronavirus, focusing solely on the effectiveness of the silver solution.
